thread.title: Thousands of Hindu pilgrims celebrate India's Kumbh Mela festival
thread.title_full: Thousands of Hindu pilgrims celebrate India's Kumbh Mela festival

title: Thousands of Hindu pilgrims celebrate India's Kumbh Mela festival
text:
Thousands of Hindu pilgrims celebrate India's Kumbh Mela festival Last updated 05:00, September 15 2015 ADNAN ABIDI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS ADNAN ABIDI/REUTERS ADNAN ABIDI/REUTERS ADNAN ABIDI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS 
A sadhu or a Hindu holy man comes out of the waters of Godavari river after taking a dip during the second 'Shahi Snan' (grand bath) at Kumbh Mela or Pitcher Festival in Nashik, India. 
A Sadhu, or Hindu holy man, leaves after taking a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
A Naga Sadhus, or Hindu holy man, reacts to the camera during a procession before taking a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
Devotees take a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
Naga Sadhus, or Hindu holy men, attend a procession before taking a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
Naga Sadhus, or Hindu holy men, wait during a procession before taking a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
Hundreds of thousands of Hindus took part in the religious gathering at the banks of the Godavari river in Nashik city at the festival, which is held every three years in different Indian cities. 
Sadhus or Hindu holy men chant religious hymns as they arrive to take a dip in the waters of Godavari river during the second 'Shahi Snan' (grand bath) at Kumbh Mela or Pitcher Festival in Nashik, India. 
A sadhu (C) or a Hindu holy man gives blessings after taking a dip in the waters of Godavari river during the second 'Shahi Snan' (grand bath) at Kumbh Mela or Pitcher Festival in Nashik, India. 
A Naga Sadhu, or Hindu holy man, jumps in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India. 
A Naga Sadhu, or Hindu holy man, waits during a procession before taking a dip in a holy pond during the second "Shahi Snan." 
A Naga Sadhu, or Hindu holy man, smokes inside his tent during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela". 1 of 12 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
Tens of thousands of Hindu pilgrims have celebrated India's Kumbh Mela festival with a dip in the Godavari river during the second bathing at Trimbakeshwar in Nasik. 
The festival, which honours the mythological victory of gods over demons, takes place every three years and sees the sadhus, or 'Godmen', dance naked with their faces painted, with tens of thousands of other pilgrims during the 'royal bath'. 
Between eight and 10 million pilgrims are expected to attend the festival, which runs until November. DANISH SIDDIQUI/REUTERS 
A Naga Sadhu, or Hindu holy man, smokes inside his tent during the second "Shahi Snan" (grand bath) at "Kumbh Mela", or Pitcher Festival, in Trimbakeshwar, India.
